revision.text:
[[Image:Thailand Bangkok and vicinity.png|thumb|200px|Map of Bangkok Metropolitan Area]] ''Not to be confused with [[Bangkok]] Metropolis, which is a reference to Bangkok's city limits.'' The '''Bangkok Metropolitan Region''' ({{lang-th|กรุงเทพมหานครและปริมณฑล}}; [[Royal Thai General System of Transcription|RTGS:]] ''Krung Thep Mahanakhon Lae Parimonthon''; [[Literal meaning|Literally:]] Bangkok and surrounding provinces), may refer to a government-defined "political definition" of the urban region surrounding the metropolis of Bangkok, or the built-up area, i.e., urban agglomeration of [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]], which varies in size and shape, and gets filled in as development expands. The political definition is defined as [[Bangkok#Administration|the metropolis]] and the five adjacent provinces of [[Nakhon Pathom Province|Nakhon Pathom]], [[Pathum Thani Province|Pathum Thani]], [[Nonthaburi Province|Nonthaburi]], [[Samut Prakan Province|Samut Prakan]], and [[Samut Sakhon Province|Samut Sakhon]]. The total area is 7,762 square kilometres. == Area and population == {{Location map+ | Bangkok Metropolitan Region |caption=
Bangkok Metropolitan Region
|float=right |width=250 |places = {{Location map~|Bangkok Metropolitan Region|mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6| lat=13.75|long=100.517|label={{nobreak|[[Bangkok]]}}|position=right}} {{Location map~|Bangkok Metropolitan Region|mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6| lat=13.768|long=100.059|label={{nobreak|[[Nakhon Pathom Province|Nakhon Pathom]]}}|position=top}} {{Location map~|Bangkok Metropolitan Region|mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6| lat=13.862|long=100.515|label={{nobreak|[[Nonthaburi Province|Nonthaburi]]}}|position=left}} {{location map~ |Bangkok Metropolitan Region |mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6 |lat=14.021|long=100.525|label={{nobreak|[[Pathum Thani Province|Pathum Thani]]}}|position=right}} {{location map~ |Bangkok Metropolitan Region |mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6 |lat=13.6|long=100.597|label={{nobreak|[[Samut Prakan Province|Samut Prakan]]}}|position=right}} {{location map~ |Bangkok Metropolitan Region |mark=Red pog.svg |marksize=6 |lat=13.548|long=100.273|label={{nobreak|[[Samut Sakhon Province|Samut Sakhon]]}}|position=left}} }} The Bangkok Metropolitan Region (political definition) covers an area of 7,761.6 km².{{cite web|title=Thailand: Bangkok Metropolitan Region / กรุงเทพมหานครและปริมณฑล|url=http://www.citypopulation.de/php/thailand-bangkokmetropolitan.php|website=City Population|accessdate=27 November 2015}} {{unreferenced section|date=May 2016}} Due to the success of the service and tourism industry in Bangkok, the city has gained in popularity for work among provincial Thais from the rural areas and with people from many countries in the Indochina region as well as many South Asian countries. In the past 20–30 years, there has been a large influx of [[Indians in Thailand|Indians into Thailand]] (especially [[Punjabis]], [[Gujarati people|Gujaratis]], [[Tamil people|Tamils]] and [[Pashtuns]]), and also [[Iranians in Thailand|Persians]], [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]], [[Khmer Krom]], [[Mon people|Mons]], [[Thai Chinese|Chinese]], as well as others emigrating to Thailand and Bangkok. There are large numbers of workers who legally reside outside the metropolitan area and travel into the city for day jobs. The population of the Bangkok metropolis ("the city") increases to nine million during the day, from eight million at night. The morning influx into the greater metropolitan region is not very significant, rather the influx is seasonal depending upon crop seasons in the rest of the country. However, during New Year's holiday, the [[Songkran (Thailand)|Songkran]] holiday, and other long weekends, the capital often seems deserted of many taxi drivers, street vendors, and other informal service providers. ==Urban build-up== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2014}} Bangkok has seen rapidly urbanization since its population reached two million in the 1960s. Since the 1980s, greater Bangkok's built-up areas have spilled beyond Bangkok's borders to neighboring provinces, initially to the north and south. Despite a general suburbanization trend, Bangkok remained centralized and the city core remained extremely dense until the early 2000s as heavy commuter traffic limited choices. The countryside between once independent towns and the capital became ever more filled in, with the advent and expansion of urban rail transit, as well as cheap credit enabling automobile adoption by the working class. The outward push of suburbanization has intensified as [[park and ride]] lots near train stations have sprung up. In a manner similar to Los Angeles, Bangkok is transforming into a region where traffic flows in all directions rather than simply to the central core, as it once did. Suburbanziation has swallowed ever more fields and swamps, though even parts of Bangkok itself are not built-up. The first areas to suburbanize were in Pathum Thani, Nonthaburi, and Samut Prakan Provinces. Other areas more recently have agglomerated in Samut Sakhon and Nakhon Pathom. Samut Prakan, Nonthaburi, Pathum Thani and Samut Sakhon all have historic city centers. Due to a lack of strict [[zoning]] laws, the metropolitan areas' growth appears haphazard. Central areas like Yaowarat, Siam, Sukhumvit, and Sathorn have seen skyrocketing land speculation as foreign investors are allowed to own condominiums, giving rise to [[Manhattanization]]. At the same time, fringe areas are being developed and the boundaries are no longer visible between each provincial city center. Due to the speed of this [[urban sprawl]] over the past twenty years, the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration has sought to tackle rising problems of commute times, pollution, and deteriorating air quality. Recent administrations have been relatively successful in tackling the air quality issue,{{cite web|url=https://coconuts.co/bangkok/news/air-bangkok-least-polluted-among-worlds-global-cities/|title=Air in Bangkok least polluted among world’s global cities|author=|date=|website=coconuts.co}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/blogs/asia/2016/12/bangkok-cleans-act-161210153606363.html|title=Bangkok cleans up its act|author=|date=|website=www.aljazeera.com}} however the city still lacks an effective mass transit network outside Bangkok proper and a clean and effective plan to resolve environmental issues. This form of urbanization is not limited to Bangkok. Traces of it can be found in metropolitan areas where there has been a surge in population. The [[Pattaya-Chonburi Metropolitan Area]] is a prime example due to the increase in residential high-rise living and the rush for commercial office space. The shared infrastructure of greater Bangkok and greater Pattaya-Chonburi, being physically close, helps fuel the latter's torrid development. === Population=== {|class="wikitable sortable" !bgcolor="#efefef"|Administrative Area !bgcolor="#efefef"|Area
km² !bgcolor="#efefef"|Population

(Jul 2017 Projection ''National Stat Office'') !bgcolor="#efefef"|Pop.Density

Pathom]]||2,168.30||815,122||942,560||''866,064''||''905,008''||1,079,400||497 |- align=right ||'''Greater Bangkok'''||7,762.00||10,159,211||14,565,520||''10,396,832''||''10,765,226''||15,931,300||2,053 |- align=right |} Sources: * http://www.citypopulation.de/php/thailand-admin.php (reporting NSO.go.th Census Data, 2010 figures subject to revision.) * http://citypopulation.de/php/thailand-prov-admin.php (reporting NSO.go.th 2017 Projections on 2010 Census data) * https://dopa.go.th/banner_link/fileDownload/130 (Dept Provincial Affairs Dec 2016) * The 2010 Census explicitly counted Thais and those with legal permanent residency status where they resided during the count.{{cite web|title=Who is included in the census?|url=http://popcensus.nso.go.th/en/index.php?id=1&sub=7|website=2010 Population and Housing Census|publisher=National Statistical Office Thailand|accessdate=27 November 2015}} The census failed to count long-stay migrants and expats without legal permanent resident status, who are estimated to number from "perhaps [two million]"{{cite news|title=A deadly cocktail|url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21572800-long-standing-worker-abuses-get-some-serious-attention-deadly-cocktail|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=The Economist|date=2013-03-02}} to "no less [sic] than 3 million"{{cite web|title=Current Migration Challenges in Thailand|url=http://eeas.europa.eu/delegations/thailand/documents/thailande_eu_coop/migration_management/3_4current_migration_challenges_in_thailand_en.pdf|website=European External Action Service|publisher=European Union External Action|accessdate=27 November 2015}} nationwide. Therefore, greater Bangkok's actual population easily surpassed 15 million by the 2010 census. * The Department of Provincial Affairs [[:th:กรมการปกครอง]] (DPA) ''Grommágaan Bpòkkrong'' registers Thai population and produces its own statistics separate from National Statistics Office (NSO). Millions live in Bangkok region with upcountry registration. Expats, migrants, those in refugee camps, and "native" ethnic tribes without Thai nationality may have not been counted DPA until 2016, when separate Thai nationality and Non-Thai was tabulated. The total registered population of 64,076,033 in 2011 was some 1.4 million fewer than census figures a year earlier.{{cite web|url=http://stat.bora.dopa.go.th/stat/y_stat54.html|title=ประกาศจำนวนประชากร ปี พ.ศ. 2554|author=|date=|website=stat.bora.dopa.go.th}} Thailand is still (2013) trying to officially register migrant workers.{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Herbert|title=Thailand: government extends a deadline for the registration of migrant workers|url=http://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=9c9cc033-62ac-4a2a-b4cb-77db75c1b9a0|website=Lexology|accessdate=27 November 2015}} * As of post-coup 2014, Thailand's Department of Employment released figures showing that 408,507 legal workers from three neighboring states, and 1,630,279 Burmese, 40,546 Laotians, and 153,683 Cambodians without legal work authorization were working and residing in Thailand.{{cite news|title=Junta: No crackdown on foreign workers| url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Junta-No-crackdown-on-foreign-workers-30236412.html|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=The Nation|date=June 17, 2014}} Nevertheless, some 180,000 Cambodians were said to have left Thailand post-coup due to rumors of a crackdown on illegals, indicating government figures may have been undercounted.{{cite news|title=Thailand, Cambodia to quash 'rumours' after worker exodus|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/archive/thailand-cambodia-to-quash-rumours-after-worker-exodus/415847|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=Bangkok Post|date=2014-06-17}} == Traffic == As of 31 October 2012, some 7,384,934 vehicles were registered in the metro area, roughly one vehicle for every two persons.{{cite news|last1=Jitsomboon|first1=Vipaporn|title=Traffic in Bangkok set to worsen in 2014, official warns|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/Traffic-in-Bangkok-set-to-worsen-in-2014-official--30196243.html|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=The Nation|date=2012-12-17}} To alleviate the ensuing congestion, massive railway development is ongoing, but its construction is causing large scale disturbance to major thoroughfares. ==Further destruction of green space== Bangkok's last undisturbed forested zone, Bang Krachao, in [[Samut Prakan Province|Samut Prakan]]'s [[Phra Pradaeng District]], also known as "the green lung" or "pig's stomach" ({{RTGS|krapho mu}}) (due to its shape) is threatened by urban sprawl, especially since a new city plan was implemented recently by Samut Prakan authorities. The plan has changed the pure green area to a "green and white" area, which allows residents to grow crops. Bang Krachao covers over 11,818 rai in six tambons in Phra Pradaeng.{{cite news|last1=Saengpassa| first1=Chularat|last2=Sarnsamak| first2=Pongphon|title=New city plan 'could ravage' the verdant Bang Krachao|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/national/New-city-plan-could-ravage-the-verdant-Bang-Kracha-30231068.html|accessdate=27 November 2015|work=The Nation|date=2014-04-08}} ==See also== * [[Bangkok Metropolitan Administration]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.dopa.go.th Ministry Of Interior Thailand] * [http://www.nso.go.th/index-1.html National Statistical Office] {{coord|13|51|N|100|25|E|display=title|region:TH_type:adm2nd_source:dewiki}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Metropolitan areas of Thailand]] [[Category:Geography of Bangkok]]

revision.text:
The '''Brussels Geographic Conference''' was held in [[Brussels]] [[Belgium]] in September 1876 at the request of King [[Leopold II of Belgium]]. At the conference were invited nearly forty well-known experts, mainly they were schooled in the geographic sciences or were wealthy [[philanthropist]]s. Before the guests returned to their respective countries, they voted to establish the [[International African Association]]. This initiative would in the end pave the way for the creation of [[Congo Free State]].
==See also== * [[Berlin Conference]] of 1884-85
==Sources== * [[Émile Banning]], ''Africa and the Brussels geographical conference'', translated by Richard Henry Major, London : Sampson Low, Marston, Searle & Rivington, 1877 * Fondation du Congo, Memoires de Emile Banning, 1927
[[Category:History of European colonialism]] [[Category:Diplomatic conferences in Belgium]] [[Category:Geography conferences]] [[Category:19th-century diplomatic conferences]] [[Category:1876 in international relations]] [[Category:1876 in Belgium]] [[Category:1876 conferences]] [[Category:19th century in Brussels]]
