{{Refimprove|date=January 2017}} The '''[[Alfalfa Club]]''', founded in 1913, is an exclusive social organization, based in [[Washington, D.C.]], in the [[United States]]. The Club's only function is the holding of an annual banquet in honor of the birthday of [[United States Civil War|Civil War]] [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] General [[Robert E. Lee]]. Its members are composed mostly of American politicians and influential members of the business community, and have included several [[Presidents of the United States]].
Members: * [[David M. Abshire]] * [[Dean Acheson]] * [[Spiro Agnew]] * [[Madeleine Albright]] * [[Neil Armstrong]] * [[James Baker]] * [[Bob Bennett (politician)|Robert F. Bennett]] * [[Joe Biden]] * [[Michael Bloomberg]] * [[David Boren]] * [[Warren Buffett]] * [[Jeb Bush]]<ref name="bush41aportrait14">{{cite book|last1=Bush|first1=George W.|title=41: A Portrait of My Father|date=2014|publisher=Ebury Publishing|location=London|isbn=9780553447781|oclc=883645289|page=14}}</ref> * [[George H. W. Bush]]<ref name="bush41aportrait14"/> * [[George W. Bush]]<ref name="bush41aportrait14"/> * [[Prescott Bush]]<ref name="bush41aportrait14"/> * [[Bill Clinton]] * [[Tom Daschle]] * [[Michael Dell]] *William T. Coleman, Jr. * [[John Foster Dulles]] * [[Steve Forbes]] * [[Gerald Ford]] * [[Newt Gingrich]] * [[Barry Goldwater]] * [[Alan Greenspan]] * [[William B. Harrison Jr.]] * [[Richard Helms]] * [[David Charles Jones]] * [[Vernon Jordan Jr.]] * [[Jack Kemp]] * [[Anthony Kennedy]] * [[John F. Kennedy]] * [[Henry Kissinger]] * [[William Knowland]] * [[Curtis LeMay]] * [[Joe Lieberman]] * [[John McCain]] * [[Neil McElroy]] * [[Walter Mondale]] * [[Robert Mondavi]] * [[Robert Mosbacher]] * [[Daniel Patrick Moynihan]] * [[Richard Nixon]] * [[Sandra Day O'Connor]] * [[Arnold Palmer]] * [[Landon Parvin]] * [[Ross Perot]] * [[Colin Powell]] * [[Ronald Reagan]] * [[William Rehnquist]] * [[Jay Rockefeller]] * [[Nelson Rockefeller]] * [[Donald Rumsfeld]] * [[James R. Schlesinger]] * [[William S. Sessions]] * [[George P. Shultz]] * [[Harry S. Truman]] * [[Earl Warren]] * [[William Westmoreland]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The Muppets'' productions}} This is a '''list of productions''' based on [[The Muppets]] characters and franchise, including films, television series and specials, and other media. The franchise's main work is ''[[The Muppet Show]]'', a syndicated television series which ran from 1976 to 1981. The franchise includes eight feature films; ''[[The Muppet Movie]]'', ''[[The Great Muppet Caper]]'', ''[[The Muppets Take Manhattan]]'', ''[[The Muppet Christmas Carol]]'', ''[[Muppet Treasure Island]]'', ''[[Muppets from Space]]'', ''[[The Muppets (film)|The Muppets]]'', and ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]''. The franchise also includes other series such as ''[[Muppets Tonight]]'' and ''[[The Muppets (TV series)|The Muppets]]''. ==Films== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:85%; width:100%;" |- ! rowspan="2" | Role |- ! ''[[The Muppet Movie]]''
(1979) ! ''[[The Great Muppet Caper]]''
(1981) ! ''[[The Muppets Take Manhattan]]''
(1984) ! ''[[The Muppet Christmas Carol]]''
(1992) ! ''[[Muppet Treasure Island]]''
(1996) ! ''[[Muppets from Space]]''
(1999) ! ''[[The Muppets (film)|The Muppets]]''
(2011) ! ''[[Muppets Most Wanted]]''
(2014) |-- ! Director | [[James Frawley]] | [[Jim Henson]] | [[Frank Oz]] | colspan="2" | [[Brian Henson]] | [[Tim Hill (director)|Tim Hill]] | colspan="2" | [[James Bobin]] |- ! page.title: List of delegates to the Millennium Summit

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Win Aung]] (link changed to [[Win Aung (minister)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
The '''[[Millennium Summit]]''' was a meeting among several world leaders that took place from September 6-8, 2000 at the [[United Nations headquarters]] in New York City in order to discuss the role of the [[United Nations]] in the turn of the 21st century. Over 150 [[head of state|heads of state]], [[head of government|heads of government]], [[crown prince]]s, [[vice president]]s, [[deputy prime minister]]s, and other [[delegate]]s attended, making this summit the largest gathering of world leaders as of the year 2000. The Millennium Summit was hosted by the United States and jointly presided over by [[President of Finland]] [[Tarja Halonen]] and [[President of Namibia]] [[Sam Nujoma]]. ==Delegations== {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin: 0 auto; text-align:center;" |+ style="margin:inherit; padding-bottom:0.25em"|'''Delegates to the Millennium Summit'''{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/millennium/participants.htm |title=List of participants at General Assembly's Millennium Summit, 6–8 September |accessdate=2007-02-07 |date=2000-09-05 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070114100618/http://www.un.org/millennium/participants.htm |archivedate=January 14, 2007 |df= }}{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/av/photo/ga/caption.htm |title=Millennium Summit Group Photo - List of Participants |accessdate=2007-02-09 |work= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001018230646/http://www.un.org/av/photo/ga/caption.htm |archivedate=2000-10-18 |df= }} |- ! Country ! Delegate ! Title ! Summit |- | [[Uruguay]] | [[Jorge Batlle Ibáñez]] | [[President of Uruguay]] |- | [[Uzbekistan]] | [[Islam Karimov]] | [[President of Uzbekistan]] |- | [[Vanuatu]] | [[Barak Sopé]] | [[Prime Minister of Vanuatu]] |- | [[Venezuela]] | [[Hugo Chávez]] | [[President of Venezuela]] |- | [[Vietnam]] | [[Trần Đức Lương]] | [[President of Vietnam]] |- | [[Yemen]] | [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] | [[President of Yemen]] |- | [[Zambia]] | [[Frederick Chiluba]] | [[President of Zambia]] |- | [[Zimbabwe]] | [[Robert Mugabe]] | [[President of Zimbabwe]] |- | | [[Kofi Annan]] | [[United Nations Secretary-General]] |} ===Co-chairs as Finland and Namibia=== The [[President of Finland]] [[Tarja Halonen]] and the [[President of Namibia]] [[Sam Nujoma]] co-chaired the Millennium Summit. This was due to the [[President of the United Nations General Assembly|Presidency over the General Assembly]] of [[Theo-Ben Gurirab]] in the [[Fifty-fourth session of the United Nations General Assembly|fifty-fourth session]] and that of [[Harri Holkeri]] in the [[Fifty-fifth session of the United Nations General Assembly|fifty-fifth session]]. Therefore, the [[Head of state|Heads of state]] of Finland and Namibia were chosen to preside over the summit.{{cite speech | title = Statement by H.E. Dr. Sam Nujoma, President of the Republic of Namibia in his capacity as co-chairman of the Millennium Summit on the occasion of the official opening of the Millennium Summit | author = | first = Sam | last = Nujoma | authorlink = Sam Nujoma | date = 2000-09-06 | location = [[United Nations Headquarters]], New York City, [[New York (state)|New York]] | url = https://www.un.org/millennium/webcast/statements/open2.htm | accessdate = 2007-02-19 }} ===Delegation of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea=== [[Kim Yong Nam]], [[Head of state]] of the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]], cancelled his visit to the Millennium Summit after an incident at an airport in [[Frankfurt, Germany]]. He and his fellow [[diplomats]] were subjected to inspection by [[American Airlines]] officials. The diplomats claimed [[diplomatic immunity]], which can free them from any law enforcement while visiting other countries.{{cite press release |title=SG/SM/7531 - Secretary-General regrets decision by Democratic People's Republic of Korea not to attend Millennium Summit following airport incident |publisher=[[United Nations]] Office of the Spokesman for the [[United Nations Secretary-General|Secretary-General]] [[Kofi Annan]] |date=2000-09-05 |url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2000/20000905.sgsm7531.doc.html |accessdate=2007-02-12 |quote= }}{{cite news|first= |last=Garrett |authorlink= |author= |coauthors= |title=North Korea complains of rude treatment, cancels trip to U.N. Millennium Summit |url=http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/east/09/05/korea.delegation/ |format= |work= |publisher=[[CNN|CNN.com]] |id= |pages= |page= |date=2000-09-06 |accessdate=2007-02-15 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070329012311/https://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/east/09/05/korea.delegation/ |archivedate=2007-03-29 |df= }} ===Delegation of Tuvalu=== [[Tuvalu]] was admitted to the United Nations the day before the Millennium Summit began, on September 5, 2000. This country was accepted as the 189th member of the United Nations, signifying Tuvalu's major development since its independence in 1978.{{cite web |url= http://www.scienceblog.com/community/older/archives/L/2000/B/un001389.html|title= Millennium Assembly elects Harri Holkeri (Finland) President, Admits Tuvalu as 189th United Nations Member State |accessdate=2007-02-16 |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2000-09-05 |year= |month= |work= |publisher=Science Blog |pages= |quote= }} ==See also== * [[List of foreign ministers in 2000]] * [[List of state leaders in 2000]] * [[Millennium Summit]] * [[United Nations member states]] ==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]] (French: Bailliage de Guernesey) is a British [[Crown dependency]] in the [[English Channel]] off the coast of [[Normandy]].
==Bailiwick includes== As well as the island of Guernsey itself, it also includes:<ref name=coysh>{{cite book|last=Coysh|first=Victor|title=Channel Islets|year=1985|publisher=Guernsey Press|location=Guernsey|isbn=0902550128}}</ref> [[File:Alderney aerial-4.jpg|thumb|200px|Alderney (centre) and [[Burhou]] (upper right)]] [[File:Les Casquets.JPG|thumb|250px|Aerial photograph of Les Casquets]]
* '''[[Alderney]]''' together with: ** [[Burhou]]<ref name=Gull/> ** [[Ortac]] ** [[Les Casquets]] ** Houmet des Pies ** Île de Raz<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.visitalderney.com/locations/fort-ile-de-raz/ |title=Fort Ile de Raz |publisher=Visit Alderney}}</ref> ** L'Étac de la Quoire<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.flora.org.gg/Eco10.htm |title=Region 8. Longis Bay and Essex Hill to Bluestone Bay; |publisher=Flora.org.gg}}</ref> ** Houmet de Clonque<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.landmarktrust.org.uk/search-and-book/properties/fort-clonque-7423 |title=Fort Clonque |publisher=The Landmark Trust}}</ref> *'''[[Sark]]''' together with: ** [[Brecqhou]] (Brechou)<ref name=Gull/> *** Le Nesté ** Les Burons<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/74492040@N04/6709363747 |title=Les Burons, Sark}}</ref> ** Baleine ** Moie de Pot ** Moie de Brenière<ref name=Gull/> ** Moie de Port Gorey ** Moie de la Bretagne ** Moie de la Fontaine ** Moie de Gouliot ** Moie de Mouton ** Tintageu ** Les Autelets<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/les-autelets-sark-136523 |title=Les Autelets, Sark}}</ref> *** Le Grand Autelet *** L'Épile *** Le Blanc Autelet (Le Petit Autelet) ** Bec du Nez (Oystercatcher’s Rock) ** La Petite Moie<ref name=Gull/> ** La Grande Moie<ref name=Gull/> ** L'Étac de Serk<ref name="Gull">{{cite web |url=http://www.paulveron.com/gullbreeding%20sites%20-%20burhou.html |title=Gull Breeding Sites in the Bailiwick of Guernsey}}</ref> ** La Noire Pute [[File:Herm, Sark and Jethou.jpg|thumb|right|260px|An aerial shot showing Herm (centre), [[Jethou]] to the right, [[Sark]] in the right background and [[Guernsey]] in the foreground]] *'''[[Herm]]''' together with: **[[Caquorobert]] ** [[Jethou]]<ref name=Gull/> *** [[Crevichon]]<ref name=Gull/> *** Fauconnière<ref name=Gull/> *** Goubinnière *** Les Ferrières *** Les Ânons *'''[[Guernsey]]''' together with: ** [[Lihou]]<ref name=Gull/> ** [[Lihoumel]] ** [[Les Houmets]] ** [[Bréhon Tower|Bréhon]] [[File:Guernsey, Les Hanois, July 2010 93.jpg|thumb|right|400px|View of the lighthouse and Les Hanois reef]] ** Les Hanois<ref name=coysh /> (see also ''[[Les Hanois Lighthouse]]'') *** Le Bisé *** Le Grand Hanois *** Le Petit Hanois *** La Percée *** Round Rock *** La Grosse Rocque ** Les Tas de Pois d'Amont<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/pierre-auguste-renoir-moulin-huet-bay-guernsey/*/x/-168/y/-82/z/2 |title=Moulin Huet Bay, Guernsey about 1883, Pierre-Auguste Renoir}}</ref> ** Les Tas de Pois d'Aval ** La Grosse Rocque<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/guernsey/content/articles/2009/05/11/grosse_rocque_flag_2009_feature.shtml |title=2009 Liberation Grosse Rocque flag raised |publisher=BBC}}</ref> ** La Platte Fougère<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ronacrete.co.uk/platte-fougere-lighthouse-guernsey.7893.aspx |title=Flashy Concrete Repair}}</ref> ** La Conchée<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/guernsey/content/articles/2009/02/20/mv_prosperity_memorial_feature.shtml |title=MV Prosperity Memorial |publisher=BBC}}</ref>

page.title: List of place names in Canada of Indigenous origin

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Indigenous Peoples of Canada}} This '''list of place names in Canada of Indigenous origin''' contains Canadian places whose names originate from the words of the [[First Nations]], [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]], or [[Inuit]], collectively referred to as [[Indigenous peoples in Canada|Indigenous peoples]]. When possible the original word or phrase used by Indigenous peoples is included, along with its generally believed meaning. Names listed are only those used in English or French, as many places have alternate names in the local native languages, e.g. [[Alkali Lake, British Columbia]] is ''Esket'' in the [[Shuswap language]]; [[Lytton, British Columbia]] is ''[[Camchin]]'' in the [[Thompson language]] (often used in English however, as Kumsheen).
==Canada== The name ''Canada'' comes from the word meaning "village" or "settlement" in the [[Laurentian language|Saint-Lawrence Iroquoian]]<ref>Bruce G. Trigger and James F. Pendergast. (1978), "Saint-Lawrence Iroquoians", in ''Handbook of North American Indians''. Volume 15. Washington: Smithsonian Institution, pp. 357–361</ref> language spoken by the inhabitants of [[Stadacona]] and the neighbouring region near present-day [[Quebec City]] in the 16th century.<ref>Jacques Cartier. (1545).''[http://www.gutenberg.org/files/12356/12356-h/12356-h.htm Relation originale de Jacques Cartier]''. Paris, Tross, 1863 edition, page 48.</ref> Another contemporary meaning was "land."<ref>Alan Rayburn. (2001). ''Naming Canada: stories about Canadian place names'', 2nd ed. ({{ISBN|0-8020-8293-9}}) University of Toronto Press: Toronto; p. 13.</ref> Jacques Cartier was first to use the word "Canada" to refer not only to the village of [[Stadacona]], but also to the neighbouring region and to the Saint-Lawrence River.
In other Iroquoian languages, the words for "town" or "village" are similar: the [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] use ''kaná:ta’'',<ref>Mithun, Marianne (1999). The Languages of Native North America. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press</ref><ref>Bright (2004:78)</ref> the [[Seneca language|Seneca]] ''iennekanandaa'', and the [[Onondaga language|Onondaga]] use ''ganataje''.<ref>Rayburn, ''op. cit'', p. 14.</ref>
==Provinces and territories== Provinces and territories whose official names are aboriginal in origin are [[Yukon]], Saskatchewan, [[Manitoba]], Ontario<!--?-->, [[Quebec]] and [[Nunavut]].
* [[Manitoba]]: Either derived from the [[Cree]] word ''manito-wapâw'' meaning "the strait of the spirit or manitobau" or the [[Assiniboine language|Assiniboine]] words ''mini'' and ''tobow'' meaning "Lake of the Prairie", referring to [[Lake Manitoba]]. * [[Nunavut]]: "Our land" in [[Inuktitut]]. * [[Ontario]]: Derived from the [[Wyandot language|Huron]] word ''onitariio'' meaning "beautiful lake", or ''kanadario'' meaning "sparkling" or "beautiful" water. * [[Quebec]]: from the [[Mi'kmaq language|Míkmaq]] word ''kepék'', meaning "strait" or "narrows".<ref>Afable, Patricia O. and Madison S. Beeler (1996). "Place Names". In "Languages", ed. Ives Goddard. Vol. 17 of ''Handbook of North American Indians'', ed. William C. Sturtevant. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Institution, pg. 191</ref> * [[Saskatchewan]]: Derived from the [[Cree]] name for the [[Saskatchewan River]], ''kisiskāciwani-sīpiy'', meaning "swift flowing river". * [[Yukon]]: from an [[Athabaskan languages|Athabaskan language]], e.g. [[Koyukon language|Koyukon]] ''yookkene'' or [[Lower Tanana language|Lower Tanana]] ''yookuna''.<ref>Bright (2004:583)</ref>
==By province and territory==
===Alberta=== * [[Amisk, Alberta|Amisk]]: "[[Beaver]]" in Cree. * [[Athabasca River]], [[Lake Athabasca]], [[Athabasca Falls]], [[Mount Athabasca]], [[Athabasca, Alberta|Athabasca]]: "Where there are reeds" in [[Cree language|Cree]] * [[Bow River]] English translation of Blackfoot name for the river - Makhabn, "river where bow reeds grow" (Blackfoot), reeds there were good for making bows with which to shoot arrows. * Chipewyan: "duck lake" <ref>Dempsey, 1969</ref> * Crowfoot Trail (Calgary) * Goosequill Lake translation of Cree word Manikwanan for the lake <ref>Holmgren and Holmgren, 1972</ref> * Grand Forks: translation of Blackfoot name for the place * Grand Prairie: translation of Cree name "Big Prairie" * Ipiatik Lake <ref>Aubrey, p.159</ref> * Kakisa River <ref name="Aubrey, p.172">Aubrey, p.172</ref> * Kakwa River <ref name="Aubrey, p.172"/> * [[Kananaskis Country|Kananaskis]] * Kapasiwin <ref name="Aubrey, p.173">Aubrey, p.173</ref> * Kapawe'no First Nation <ref name="Aubrey, p.173"/> * Kimiwan: Cree word for rainy * [[Lake Minnewanka]]: ""Water of the Spirits" in [[Sioux language|Sioux]] (Nakoda/Stoney language) * Makaoo Indian Reserve. Cree name of early leader of the Band <ref name="ReferenceA">Harrison, Place Names of Alberta, volume 3</ref> * Manawan Lake Cree for egg-gathering place <ref name="ReferenceA"/> * Marie Lake poor translation of the Cree word for the place methai, pronounced merai, which translates as a fish.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * Maskekosikh Trail (formerly 23rd Avenue between 215th Street and Anthony Henday Drive) Road of the "people of the land of medicine" in Cree<ref>"Renamed Maskekosikh Trail part of City's ongoing reconciliation committment," CBC News, Feb. 12, 2016</ref> * Maskwa Creek near Wetaskiwin Cree word for black bear is muskwa * Matchayaw Lake Cree for bad spirit. Palliser translated the name as Little Manitoo in 1865.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * [[Medicine Hat]]: Translation of the [[Blackfoot language|Blackfoot]] word ''saamis'', meaning "headdress of a medicine man". * Meeting Creek. English translation of the Cree name nukh-kwa-ta-to, which referenced the frequent meeting between the Cree and Blackfoot there.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * Metiskow Cree for many trees <ref>Aubrey, p.210</ref> * Mewassin Native word for good <ref name="ReferenceA"/> * Michichi: Cree for hand (Nearby Hand Hills has same source) * Mitsue Creek <ref>Aubrey, p.215</ref> * Mokowan Ridge <ref>Aubrey, p.217</ref> * Minaik: Cree (also Nakoda) "Minahik" for evergreen (pine or tamarack) * [[Nikanassin Range]]: "First range" in [[Cree language|Cree]] * [[Okotoks]]: "[[Big Rock (glacial erratic)|Big Rock]]" in [[Blackfoot language|Blackfoot]] * Oldman River. The Piikani Nation of the Blackfoot Confederacy named the river after their traditional sacred ground at its headwaters, said to the "Old Man's Playing Ground," sacred ground of Napi, the Old Man, the Great Creator.<ref>"Oldman River," Historica Canada website</ref> * Papaschase Industrial Park (Edmonton) * [[Ponoka, Alberta|Ponoka]]: "Black Elk" in [[Blackfoot language|Blackfoot]] * Sakaw (neighbourhood in southside Edmonton) * [[Saskatchewan River]], North and South Saskatchewan River * Shaganappi Trail (Calgary). Shaganappi were rawhide strips. Used to repair a myriad of objects, it was the duct tape of its time. * Skyrattler (neighbourhood in southside Edmonton) * [[Slave Lake]]: "Slave" was a mis-translation of the Cree word for foreigner to describe the Athabaskan people living there. (see Slave River, NWT below) * [[Smoky Lake]]: This town's name comes from the Cree name for the almost-now-disappeared lake nearby. Wood Cree named it Smoking Lake for either the large number of campfires around it often, or the unusually large quantities of mist that came off it at sunset. * Tipaskan (neighbourhood in southside Edmonton) * Valley of Ten Peaks includes these four peaks named after the numerals of the Stoney language: Mount Tonsa (no. four); Mount Tuzo (no. 7); Neptuak Mountain (no. 9) and Wenkchemna Peak (no. 10). * [[Wabasca, Alberta|Wabasca]]: from ''wapuskau'', "grassy narrows" in [[Cree language]] * [[Wapiti River]]: from the [[Cree language|Cree]] word for "elk", ''waapiti'' (literally "white rump"). * [[Waputik Range]]: ''Waputik'' means "white goat" in [[Nakoda (Stoney)|Stoney]] * Waskatenau village and creek. pronounced with silent "k." In 1880s area was home to the Wah-Sat-Now (Cree) band, which later moved to the Saddle Lake reserve.<ref>Edmonton Bulletin, Jan. 3, 1881; April 18, 1885; Sept. 16, 1897</ref> Cree term for "opening in the banks", in reference to the clef in the nearby ridge through which the Waskatenau Creek flows.<ref>Harrison, Volume 3</ref> * [[Wetaskiwin]]: "Place of peace" or "hill of peace" in [[Cree language|Cree]]
===British Columbia=== For the scores of BC placenames from the Chinook Jargon, see [[List of Chinook Jargon placenames]].
====A-B==== * Ahnuhati River: "where the [[pink salmon|humpback salmon]] go" in [[Kwak'wala]] * [[Ahousat, British Columbia|Ahousat]]: "people living with their backs to the mountains" in [[Nuu-chah-nulth language|Nuu-chah-nulth]] (Nootka). * [[Aiyansh, British Columbia|Aiyansh]] and [[New Aiyansh, British Columbia|New Aiyansh]]: "early leaves" or "leafing early" in the [[Nisga'a language]] * [[Akamina Pass]]: "mountain pass" in [[Ktunaxa]] (Kootenay) * [[Akie River]]: "cut-bank river" in [[Dunne-za]] * [[Amiskwi River]]: "beaver trail" in [[Cree language|Cree]] * [[Anyox, British Columbia|Anyox]]: "place of hiding" in [[Nisga'a language|Nisga'a]] * [[Ashlu Creek]] * [[Ashnola River]]: thought to mean "white water" in [[Okanagan language|Okanagan]] * [[Asitka River]], [[Asitka Peak]], [[Asitka Lake]] * [[Askom Mountain]]: "mountain" in [[St'at'imcets]] (the Lillooet language) * [[Atchelitz]]: "bay" or "inlet" in [[Halqemeylem]], * [[Atlin, British Columbia|Atlin]]: "big lake" in [[Tlingit language|Inland Tlingit]] * [[Atna Range]]: "strangers" or "other people" in [[Carrier language|Carrier]]. * [[Atnarko River]]: "river of strangers" in [[Chilcotin language|Chilcotin]] * [[Atsutla Range]] * [[Attachie]]: the name of a [[Beaver indian]] whose descendants are members of the nearby [[Doig River First Nation]] * [[Bella Coola, British Columbia|Bella Coola]]: Named for the usual term for the local indigenous people, who call themselves [[Nuxalk Nation|Nuxalk]]. ''Bella Coola'' is an adaption of {{IPA-sal|bəlxwəla|}}, the Heiltsuk name for the Nuxalk; their meaning is not limited to the band at Bella Coola but to all Nuxalk. * [[Bella Bella, British Columbia|Bella Bella]]: This is an adaption of the [[Heiltsuk people|Heiltsuk]] name for themselves, {{IPA-sal|pəlbálá|}}. * [[Botanie Mountain]], Botanie Creek, Botanie Valley etc., meaning "covered", "covering" or "blanketed all over" in [[Thompson language|Nlaka'pamux (Thompson)]], which is thought to be a reference to its shroud of cloud or fog in times of bad weather, or else a reference to the abundant plant cover in the area. An 1894 account of a [[Shuswap language|Secwepemc (Shuswap)]] meaning is "many root place" (the upper end of the Botanie Valley is near the limit of Secwepemc territory)
====C==== * [[Canim Lake (British Columbia)|Canim Lake]], [[Canim River]], [[Canim Falls]], [[Canim Beach Provincial Park]]: "canoe" in the [[Chinook Jargon]] * [[Cariboo]]: from the [[Mi'kmaq language]] ''xalibu'' or ''Qalipu'' via French ''caribou'' (1610) ''cariboeuf'' or ''carfboeuf'': "pawer" or "scratcher".<ref name="caribou">[http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=caribou&allowed_in_frame=0 Online Etymology Dictionary, 'caribou']</ref><ref name=HWW>{{citation|url=http://www.hww.ca/en/species/mammals/caribou.html |origyear=1985 |year=2005 |ISBN=0-662-39659-6 |work=Canadian Wildlife Service/EC |title=Hinterland Who's Who |editor-first=Maureen |editor-last=Kavanagh |accessdate=21 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224105839/http://www.hww.ca/en/species/mammals/caribou.html |archivedate=24 December 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref group=Notes>[[Marc Lescarbot]] in his publication in French [http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/21221/pg21221.txt 1610] used the term "caribou." [[Silas Tertius Rand]] included the term Kaleboo in his Mi'kmaq-English [http://islandstories.ca/island_stories_viewer/ilives:230896/Charlottetown dictionary] in 1888.</ref> A mountain subspecies of [[caribou]] were once numerous. * Carmanah Creek, [[Carmanah Valley]], Carmanah Point: "thus far upstream" in the [[Nitinaht]] dialect of ([[Nuu-chah-nulth language|Nuu-chah-nulth]]). * [[Cassiar, British Columbia|Cassiar]]: a remote adaptation of [[Kaska]], definition debatable, but possibly "old moccasins". * [[Caycuse River]]: from the [[Nitinaht]] dialect of [[Nuu-chah-nulth language]], meaning "place where they fix up canoes". * [[Cayoosh Creek]]: ''Cayoosh'' is a [[Lillooet, British Columbia|Lillooet]]-area variant of ''cayuse'', originally from the Spanish ''caballo'' – "horse", although in Lillooet and [[Chilcotin District|the Chilcotin]] this word specifies a particular breed of Indian mountain pony. There are two versions of the name's meaning. In one account, someone's pony dropped dead in or at the creek after an arduous journey over the pass at the head of its valley. In the other, the crest of standing waves in the rushing waters of the creek are said to resemble bucking horses and their manes. * [[Celista, British Columbia]]: from the [[Secwepemc]] chiefly and family name ''Celesta'', common in the nearby community of [[Neskonlith]] near [[Chase, British Columbia|Chase]]. * [[Chaba Peak]]: from the [[Stoney language]] word for "beaver". * [[Chantslar Lake]]: from the [[Chilcotin language]] word for "steelhead lake" * [[Cheakamus River]]: from the [[Squamish language]] "[[Chiyakmesh]]", for "salmon weir place". * Cheam: Halqemeylem for "(place to) always get strawberries". The Halqemeylem term refers to an island across from the present-day reserve and village. This name is used in English for Mount Cheam ([[Cheam Peak]]), the most prominent of the Four Sisters Range east of Chilliwack, which in Halqemeylem is called Thleethleq (the name of [[Mount Baker]]'s wife, turned to stone). * [[Chechidla Range]] - from a phrase meaning "mountains of small rocks" in the [[Tahltan language]] * [[Checleset Bay]]: from the [[Nuu-chah-nulth language]] name Cheklesahht, "people of cut on the beach", the local group of [[Nuu-chah-nulth people|Nuu-chah-nulth]] people, whose band government today is the [[Kyuquot/Cheklesahht First Nation]]. * [[Chedakuz Arm]] ([[Knewstubb Lake]]), Carrier language * [[Cheewat River]]: from the Nitinaht dialect of [[Nuu-chah-nulth language|Nuu-chah-nulth]] for "having an island nearby". * [[Cheekye River]] and the locality of Cheekye near Squamish: from ''Nch'kay'', the [[Squamish language]] name for [[Mount Garibaldi]], meaning "dirty place" in reference to that mountain's ash-stained snows * [[Chehalis, British Columbia|Chehalis]] and [[Chehalis River (British Columbia)|Chehalis River]]: probable meanings vary from "the place one reaches after ascending the rapids" or "where the 'chest' of a canoe grounds on a sandbar'. The sandbar or rapids in question would be the old "riffles" of the Harrison River where it empties into the Fraser River out of Harrison Bay (the riffles were dredged out in gold rush times). The Chehalis people refer to themselves, however, as [[Sts'ailes]], "beating heart". * [[Cheja Range]] - from a phrase meaning "mountains are hard" in the [[Tahltan language]] * [[Chemainus, British Columbia|Chemainus]]: Named after the native shaman and prophet ''Tsa-meeun-is'', which means "Broken Chest" or "bitten breast"([[Halkomelem|Hulquminum language]]), a reference to the bitemarks possible during a shamanic frenzy, which the local horseshoe-shaped bay is thought to have resembled. * [[Cheslatta Lake]]: "top of small mountain" or "small rock mountain at east side" in the [[Carrier language]] * [[Chezacut]]: "birds without feathers" in the [[Chilcotin language]]. * [[Chic Chic Bay]]: ''Tshik-tshik'', under various spellings, is the Chinook Jargon for a wagon or wheeled vehicle. * [[Chikamin Range]]: ''Chickamin'', as usually spelled, is "metal" or "ore" in the [[Chinook Jargon]], often meaning simply "gold" * [[Chilako River]]: "beaver hand river" in the [[Carrier language]] * [[Chilanko River]]: "many beaver river" in the [[Chilcotin language]] * [[Chilcotin River]]: "red ochre river people" in the [[Chilcotin language]] * [[Chilkat Pass]]: "salmon storehouse" in the [[Tlingit language]] * [[Chilko River]]: "red ochre river" in the [[Chilcotin language]] * [[Chilliwack, British Columbia|Chilliwack]]: "Going back up" in [[Halkomelem language|Halqemeylem]]. Other translations are "quieter water on the head" or "travel by way of a backwater of slough", all a reference to the broad marshlands and sloughs of the Chilliwack area, which lies between the Fraser River's many side-channels and Sumas Prairie (much of formerly [[Sumas Lake]]). Older spellings are Chilliwhack, Chilliwayhook, Chil-whey-uk, Chilwayook, and Silawack. * Chinook Cove: on the [[North Thompson River]], a reference to the Chinook salmon rather than to the language, wind or people of the same name. * Choelquoit Lake: "fishtrap lake" in the [[Chilcotin language]] * Chonat Bay: "where coho salmon are found" in [[Kwak'wala]] * Chu Chua: the plural of the [[Secwepemc language]] word for "creek". * [[Chuckwalla River]]: "short river" in [[Oowekyala]]. The nearby [[Kilbella]] River means "long river". * [[Chukachida River]] * [[Chutine River]]: "half-people" in either the [[Tlinkit language|Tlinkit]] or [[Tahltan language]]s. The area's population was half-Tlingit and half-Tahltan. * [[Cinnemousun Narrows Provincial Park]]: From the [[Secwepemc language]] ''cium-moust-un'', meaning "come and go back again", sometimes translated as "the bend" (i.e. in [[Shuswap Lake]]) * [[Clayoquot Sound]]: an adaption of the Nuu-chah-nulth language Tla-o-qui-aht, which has a variety of translations: "other or different people", "other or strange house", "people who are different from what they used to be"; in Nitinaht the phrase translates as "people of the place where it becomes the same even when disturbed". * [[Clo-oose, British Columbia|Clo-oose]]: "campsite beach" in the Nitinaht dialect of [[Nuu-chah-nulth language|Nuu-chah-nulth]] * [[Clusko River]]: "mud river" in the [[Chilcotin language]] * [[Cluxewe Mountain]], [[Cluxewe River]]: "delta or sand bar" in Kwak'wala * [[Coglistiko River]]: "stream coming from small jack-pine windfalls" in the [[Carrier language]] * [[Colquitz River]]: "waterfall" in [[North Straits Salish]] * [[Comiaken, British Columbia|Comiaken]]: "bare, devoid of vegetation" in [[Hulquminum]] * [[Comaplix, British Columbia]] is a former mining town which was named after the [[Incomappleux River]] from the [[Sinixt|Lakes]] or [[Colville-Okanagan]] word nk'mapeleqs, meaning "point at end (of lake)". * [[Comox, British Columbia|Comox]]: either from the [[Chinook Jargon]] for "dog" (''kamuks''), or from the [[Kwak'wala]] for "place of plenty". * Conuma Peak: "high, rocky peak" in the [[Nuu-chah-nulth language]] * [[Coqualeetza, British Columbia|Coqualeetza]]: "place of beating of blankets (to get them clean)" in [[Halkomelem|Halqemeylem]] * [[Coquihalla River]], [[Coquihalla Mountain]]: "stingy container" (of fish) in [[Halkomelem|Halqemeylem]], a reference to black-coloured water spirits who would steal fish right off the spear * [[Coquitlam, British Columbia|Coquitlam]]: "small red [[salmon]]" in [[Halqemeylem]] (Upriver Halkomelem). Derived from the name of the ''[[Kwikwetlem]]'' people. Another and more usual translation is "stinking of fish slime" or "stinking fish", thought to be a reference to the Kwikwetlem people's role as slaves to the Katzie and Kwantlen as fish butchers. * [[Cowichan River|Cowichan]]: from ''Quwutsun'', "land warmed by the sun" or "warm country" ([[Halkomelem|Hulquminum]]) * [[Cultus Lake, British Columbia|Cultus]]: "bad, of no value, worthless" in [[Chinook jargon]]. In First Nations legend, this popular recreational lake south of Chilliwack was said to be inhabited by evil spirits. * [[Cumshewa, British Columbia|Cumshewa]], [[Cumshewa Inlet]], Cunshewa Head: Cumshewa was a prominent [[Haida people|Haida]] chief in the late 18th century, noted for the killing of the crew of the US trading vessel ''Constitution'' in 1794. His name means "rich at the mouth" (of the river)" and was conferred from the language of the [[Heiltsuk people|Heiltsuk]], who were allies of the Cumshewa Haida.
====D-J==== *[[Dil-Dil Plateau]], meaning unknown, probably [[Chilcotin language]] *Ealue Lake: "sky fish" in [[Tahltan language|Tahltan]]. *[[Ecstall River]]: from the [[Tsimshian language|Tsimshian]] for "tributary" or "something from the side" (the Ecstall joins the [[Skeena River]] near [[Prince Rupert, British Columbia|Prince Rupert]]) *[[Eddontenajon, British Columbia|Eddontenajon]]: "child crying in the water" or "a little boy drowned" in [[Tahltan language|Tahltan]] *Cape Edensaw: Edenshaw, in its modern spelling, remains an important name in modern Haida society, known mostly nowadays for the dynasty of famous carvers of that name, all descendants of the early 19th century chief of this name, one of the powerful chiefs of [[Masset, British Columbia|Masset]] *[[Mount Edziza|Edziza, Mount]] and [[Mount Edziza volcanic complex|Edziza, Mount volcanic complex]]: named after the Edzertza family of the [[Tahltan]] people, who live nearby. *[[Elaho River]] *[[Endako Lake]], Carrier language *[[Esquimalt, British Columbia|Esquimalt]]: [[North Straits Salish]] for "the place of gradually shoaling water". Derived from their word ''Es-whoy-malth''. *[[Euchuk Lake]], Carrier language *[[Fontas River]]: originally Fantasque's River, after the name of a chief of the [[Sekani]] people *[[Gataga River]], [[Gataga Lakes]], [[Gataga Mountain]], [[Gataga River]], [[Gataga Ranges]], derived from the Sekani name for the river Tadadzè' (Guzagi K'úgé)<ref>[http://apps.gov.bc.ca/pub/bcgnws/names/8076.html BC Names entry "Gataga Mountain"]</ref> *[[Gingolx, British Columbia|Gingolx]], also sp. Kincolith, "Place of skulls" in the [[Nisga'a language]] *[[Gunn Valley]], from the name of a member of the [[Xeni Gwet'in]] of [[Nemaiah Valley]] who lived there, ''ganin''. *[[Hotnarko River]] *[[Hozameen Range]] *[[Hunlen Falls]], from the name of a chief whose trapline was in the area of the falls *[[Incomappleux River]] is from the [[Sinixt|Lakes]] or [[Colville-Okanagan]] word nk'mapeleqs, meaning "point at end (of lake)". The name of the former town of Comaplix and adjacent mountain and creek are derived from the name of the river. *[[Inklin River]] *[[Kinuseo Falls]], from the Cree for "fish"
====K-L==== *[[Kalamalka Lake]] *[[Kamloops, British Columbia|Kamloops]]: anglicization of the [[Shuswap language|Shuswap]] word ''Tk'emlups'', meaning "where the rivers meet". *[[Kasalka Range]], [[Kasalka Butte]], Kasalka Creek *[[Kelowna, British Columbia|Kelowna]]: "ki?lawna?" meaning a male [[grizzly bear]] in the [[Okanagan]] language. *[[Kemano]], from the name of one of the subdivisions of the Henaksiala people, a subgroup of the [[Haisla people|Haisla]] *[[Keremeos, British Columbia|Keremeos]] *[[Khutzeymateen River]], [[Khutzeymateen Provincial Park]], [[Khutzeymateen Inlet]], from "K'tzim-a-deen" (Tsimshian language) *Kincolith – see Gingolx *[[Kitimat]]- people of the snow *[[Kitlope River]], var. of Gitlope, the Tsimshian language name for the Gitlope, "people of the rocks", now amalgamated with the Gitamaat band as the [[Haisla First Nation]]. *[[Kitselas, British Columbia]], [[Kitselas Canyon]], "people of the village in the canyon" in the [[Tsimshian language]] *[[Kitsumkalum, British Columbia]], [[Kitsumkalum River]] – "people of the riffles (in the shallow water" in the [[Tsimshian language]]. *[[Klemtu]], from the [[Coast Tsimshian language]] "Klemdoo-oolk," meaning"impassable"<ref>{{BCGNIS|28410|Klemtu}}</ref> *[[Kluskus Lakes]], [[Kluskus Hills]], [[Kluskus, British Columbia|Kluskus]] *[[Kootenays|Kootenay]]: derived from the proper name of the Kootenay people, [[Ktunaxa]] *[[Kuyakuz Mountain]], [[Kuyakuz Lake]] *[[Kwadacha River]] "white water" in [[Sekani language|Sekani]] (indigenous spelling Kwàdàta or Kwodàch). The river contains high amounts of rock flour, so "white" is reference to the colour of the water, not to rapids.<ref>{{BCGNIS|13444|Kwadacha River}}</ref> **[[Kwadacha Glacier]] **[[Kwadacha Mountain]] **[[Kwadacha Wilderness Provincial Park]] **[[Kwadacha, British Columbia]] (Fort Ware) *[[Lakelse Lake]], [[Lakelse Lake Provincial Park]], [[Lakelse Hot Springs]] etc. from the Coast Tsimshian "LaxGyels"<!--meaning unknown as yet--> *[[Kyuquot, British Columbia]], [[Kyuquot Sound]] – from the name of the local group of Nuu-chah-nulth *[[Lillooet, British Columbia|Lillooet]]: adapted from the proper name for the Lower [[St'at'imc]] people, the Lil'wat of [[Mount Currie, British Columbia|Mt. Currie]]. Lil'wat means "wild onions". The old name of Lillooet was Cayoosh Flat (1858–1860), derived from the name of one of the streams converging into the Fraser at the town (''cayoosh'' is the local variant of Chinook Jargon for "horse" or "Indian pony").
====M-N==== *[[Malahat, British Columbia|Malahat]] *[[Malakwa, British Columbia|Malakwa]]: from [[Chinook Jargon]] ''malakwa'' for "mosquito(s)" (from fr. ''le maringouin''). *[[Mamquam River]] *[[Marktosis, British Columbia|Marktosis]] *[[Masset, British Columbia|Masset]] – a Haida adaptation of a Spanish captain's name, possibly Masseta or Massetta *[[Matsqui, British Columbia|Matsqui]]: ″stretch of higher ground″ *[[Mehatl Creek]] *[[Mesilinka River]] *[[Metchosin, British Columbia|Metchosin]]: English translation of ''Smets-Schosen'', meaning "place of stinking fish" *[[Metsantan Pass]], [[Metsantan Range]] – "People of the Caribou Hide" in [[Kaska language|Kaska]]. Also the name of the former settlement of Metsantan, aka Caribou Hide, and of [[Metsantan Creek]] and [[Metsantan Lake]]<ref>{{BCGNIS|50638|Caribou Hide (community)}}</ref> *[[Misinchinka River]] *[[Mount Tzouhalem]], after the [[Quamichan]] chief and warrior who was banished there. *[[Muskwa River]], "bear" in the [[Cree language]]. *[[Naglico Lake]], [[Naglico Hills]] *[[Nadina River]], [[Nadina Mountain]] – the name of the river is derived from that of Nadina Mountain, which is near its source, the name of which means "standing up alone" in the [[Carrier language]]. The river's actual name in Carrier, not adopted by the geographical names board, is "Nadinako".<ref>{{BCGNIS|8988|Nadina River}}</ref> *[[Nahatlatch River]], [[Nahatlatch Needle]] *[[Nakina River]] *[[Nakusp, British Columbia|Nakusp]] – from the [[Sinixt]] or [[Okanagan language]] word "Neqo'sp" meaning "closed-in" or "safe"<ref>{{BCGNIS|38677|Nakusp (village)}}</ref> *[[Namu, British Columbia|Namu]] *[[Nanaimo]]: Named after the [[Snuneymuxw]] people. *[[Nanoose Bay]] *[[Natalkuz Lake]] *[[Nazko, British Columbia|Nazko]] – "river flowing from the south" in [[Carrier language|Carrier]]<!--maybe also in Tsilhqot'in--> *[[Nechako River]]: An anglicization of {{IPA-ath|netʃa koh|}}, its name in the indigenous [[Carrier language]] which means "big river". *[[Nemaiah Valley]], from Nemiah, name of the founding chief who moved there from [[Hanceville, British Columbia|Hanceville]] *[[Nicolum River]] *[[Nicoamen River]], [[Nicoamen Plateau]] *[[Nicolum River]], [[Nicolum River Provincial Park]] *[[Nicomekl River]] – [[Halq'emeylem]] for "the route to go" or "the pathway". *[[Nicomen Island]] *[[Nimpkish River]], from the name of the [['Namgis]], the [[Kwakwaka'wakw]] people whose territory this river is in. *[[Nimpo Lake]] *[[Nitinat Lake]]: from the usual English spelling of the name of the [[Ditidaht]] people *[[Noaxe Lake]], [[Noaxe Creek]]
====O-Q==== *[[Okanagan]]: *[[Omineca River]], [[Omineca Mountains]], [[Omineca Country]] *[[Ominicetla River]]<!--Creek?--> *[[Ootsa Lake]] *[[Opitsaht, British Columbia|Opitsaht]] *[[Osilinka River]] *[[Osoyoos, British Columbia|Osoyoos]]: From ''suius'' in the [[Okanagan language]], meaning "Narrowing of the waters"; the O- prefix was added by English speakers to harmonize with Okanagan and other O-placenames in the area such as Omak, Oroville and Oliver. *[[Ospika River]] *[[Pasayten River]] *[[Penticton]]: "Place to stay forever" in [[Okanagan language|Okanagan]] *[[Popkum, British Columbia|Popkum]]: "puffball mushrooms" in [[Halqemeylem]] *[[Qualicum Beach, British Columbia|Qualicum Beach]], [[Qualicum River]]: "Where the dog salmon run" in [[Comox language|Comox]] *[[Quanchus Range]] *[[Quatsino Sound]], [[Quatsino Provincial Park]], [[Quatsino, British Columbia]], from [[Gwat'sinux]], the name of the local group of [[Kwakwaka'wakw]] people. *[[Quilchena, British Columbia|Quilchena]]:
====S==== *[[Saanich, British Columbia|Saanich]]: from [[WSANEC]], the name of one of the local [[Straits Salish]] peoples and their language. *[[Sechelt, British Columbia|Sechelt]]: the town is named after the [[Shishalh]] people who live in the area *[[Shalalth, British Columbia|Shalalth]]: From ''Ts'alalh'', "the lake" in the [[St'at'imcets]] language of the [[St'at'imc|Lillooet]] people *[[Shulaps Range]], [[Shulaps Peak]]: "ram of the mountain sheep" in the [[Chilcotin language]]. *[[Sicamous, British Columbia|Sicamous]] – "river circling mountains" in the [[Shuswap language]].<ref>{{BCGNIS|19504|Sicamous (district municipality)}}</ref> *[[Sikanni Chief River]] *[[Siska, British Columbia|Siska]] – from ''sisqa'', [[Thompson language]] (Nlaka'pamux) for "uncle" *[[Skaha Lake]]: from the Okanagan language word for "dog" (''sqexe''). Skaha Lake in frontier times was often called Dog Lake, although that is the [[Shuswap language]] meaning of ''skaha''; in the [[Okanagan language]] it means "horse" or "pony". *[[Skaist Mountain]], [[Skaist River]] *[[Skeena River]] - from "X'san", [[Tsimshian]] (Gitksan) for "River of Mist" *[[Skihist Mountain]] and [[Skihist Provincial Park]] *[[Skidegate, British Columbia|Skidegate]] *[[Skookumchuck, British Columbia|Skookumchuck]]: "strong (skookum) ocean/water (chuck); that is: "strong tide, strong ocean current, rapids" in [[Chinook Jargon]] (three different locations – Sechelt Inlet, Lillooet River, Columbia River/East Kootenay, though also has a general meaning of a tidal rapids, usually at the mouth of an inlet). *[[Similkameen River|Similkameen]]: From "Similkameugh" or "Samilkameigh" or "Samilkumeigh" meaning "white swan", one of the twelve tribes of the [[Okanagan people]]. The "-meen" ending was "forced by the whites" on this name to harmonize with the name of the river's tributary, the [[Tulameen River|Tulameen]]. *[[Slocan, British Columbia|Slocan]] and [[Slocan River]]: Slhu?kin Meaning "speared in the head" in the [[Sinixt|Lakes]] dialect of the [[Colville-Okanagan]] language and in reference to the traditional method of spear fishing in the region with a three pronged fish spear, a "lhumin." *[[Sloko River]] *[[Somass River]] *[[Sooke, British Columbia|Sooke]]: named after the [[T'Souke]] people who live in the area *[[Spallumcheen, British Columbia|Spallumcheen]] *[[Spatsizi River]] and associated placenames *[[Spillimacheen River]], [[Spillimacheen, British Columbia|Spillimacheen]] *[[Spuzzum, British Columbia|Spuzzum]], from the local variant of the Chinook Jargon ''spatsum'', a reed used in basketry *[[Squamish, British Columbia|Squamish]] and [[Squamish River]]: The river and the town are named after the [[Squamish people]] who live in the area *[[Stein River]]: Adjacent to Lytton BC, "Stein" is an adaptation of the Nlaka'pamux (Thompson) ''staygn'' – "hidden place". *[[Stellako River]], [[Stellako, British Columbia|Stellako]] *[[Stikine River]] and associated placenames. From ''Shta-KEEN'', "great river" in the [[Tlingit language]] *[[Sumallo River]] *[[Sumas Lake]], [[Sumas River]], [[Sumas Mountain (British Columbia)|Sumas Mountain]], and the old [[Sumas, British Columbia|District of Sumas]] (now part of Abbotsford): from a Halqemeylem language word for ""a big level opening"
====T==== *[[Taghum, British Columbia]], ''taghum'' is the Chinook Jargon word for "six" (Taghum is six miles from [[Nelson, British Columbia|Nelson]]) *[[Tagish Lake]], [[Tagish Highland]] – "fish trap" ''or'' "it (spring ice) is breaking up" in the [[Tagish language]] *[[Tahltan, British Columbia|Tahltan]], [[Tahltan River]], [[Little Tahltan River]], [[Tahltan Highland]], a [[Tlingit language]] word for "something heavy in the water" (i.e. salmon), originally applied to the settlement, extended from there to become the name of the Tahltan people *[[Tahsis, British Columbia|Tahsis]] *[[Tahtsa Lake]], [[Tahtsa Peak]], [[Tahtsa Ranges]] *[[Talchako River]], [[Talchako Pass]] *[[Takla Lake]], [[Takla Landing]] *[[Taku River]], [[Taku Plateau]] and the [[Taku Arm]] of [[Tagish Lake]] from the name of the [[Taku people]] *[[Talchako River]] *[[Tanzilla River]], [[Tanzilla Plateau]] *[[Taseko Mountain]], [[Taseko River]], [[Taseko Lakes]] – from the [[Chilcotin language]] ''"Desiqox"'', which means "Mosquito River". *[[Tatla Lake]] *[[Tatlatui Provincial Park]], [[Tatlatui Lake]], [[Tatlatui Peak]] *[[Tatlayoko Lake]] *[[Tchaikazan River]], from the [[Chilcotin language]] name for a peak visible from its valley, ''Ts^icheza'on''. *[[Teslin Lake]] and [[Teslin, British Columbia]], from the name of the local group of [[Tlingit people|Inland Tlinkit]] *[[Tochquonyalla Range]] *[[Toodoggone River]], originally "Thudegade" and from the [[Kaska language]] ''Tuhfa Ughane'' meaning "Two Brothers River'' or "eagles nest"<ref>{{BCGNIS|27295|Toodoggone River}}</ref> *[[Ts'il?os Provincial Park]], also Ts'il?os, Ts'ylos, Ts'yl-os, Tsoloss, the Chilcotin language name for [[Mount Tatlow]] *[[Tulameen, British Columbia|Tulameen]]: [[Nlaka'pamux]] (Thompson) language for "red earth", a reference to the ochre found here. *[[Tuya River]], [[Tuya Lake]], [[Tuya Range]], [[Little Tuya River]] *[[Tsawwassen]]: "Looking toward the sea" in [[North Straits Salish]]<!--not Downriver Halkomelem??--> *[[Tyoax Pass]], at the head of Tyaughton Creek (see next) *[[Tyaughton Lake]], [[Tyaughton Creek]] (also Tyoax, Tyax), from the [[Chilcotin language]] for "jumping fish" *[[Tyhee Lake Provincial Park]]: ''Tyhee'' is a variant of the usual [[Chinook Jargon]] ''tyee'' – "chief, big, great, important, boss"
====U-Z==== *[[Ucluelet]]: "people of the safe harbour" in the language of the Nuu-chah-nulth. *[[Unuk River]] *[[Wannock River]], "poison" in [[Wuikyala]] *[[Wapiti River]] *[[Whonnock, British Columbia|Whonnock]], [[Whonnock Lake]], Whonnock Creek: from ''honnock'', "humpback salmon" in [[Halqemeylem]], the only variety of salmon to spawn in Whonnock Creek. *[[Yalakom River]], [[Yalakom Mountain]]: "ewe of the mountain sheep" in the [[Chilcotin language]] *[[Yohetta Valley]], [[Yohetta Creek]], [[Yohetta Lake]], from the [[Tsilhqot'in language]] ''yuyetabin'' [where bin means lake] *[[Yoho National Park]] – "Yoho" means "how amazing" or "it is beautiful"<!--in which language?--> *[[Yuquot]], the Nuu-chah-nulth language name, meaning "winds come from all directions", for the village usually known in English as Friendly Cove, on [[Nootka Sound]] *[[Zagoddetchino Mountain]] *[[Zus Mountain]] *[[Zymoetz River]]
===Manitoba=== *[[Grand Rapids, Manitoba|Grand Rapids]]: Translation of [[Cree]] word ''misepawistik'', meaning "rushing rapids". *[[The Pas, Manitoba|The Pas]]: From French ''Le Pas,'' a shortening of ''Fort Pascoyac'', from the Pasquia River, named for the [[Opaskwayak Cree Nation]]. *[[Wapusk National Park]]: from ''wâpask'', "polar bear" in [[Cree language]] *[[Winnipeg]]: "muddy water" from the word ''win-nipi'' of the [[Cree]].
===New Brunswick===<!-- This section is linked from [[History of New Brunswick]]. See [[WP:MOS#Section management]] --> * [[Apohaqui, New Brunswick|Apohaqui]] – translated from the [[Maliseet]] language, and means "The joining of two waters" or "the joining of two rivers". (Apohaqui is where the [[Millstream River (New Brunswick)|Millstream]] and the [[Kennebecasis River]] join.) * [[Aroostook, New Brunswick|Aroostook]] * [[Bouctouche]]: a corruption of the Mi'kmaq word Chebooktoosk, meaning Great Little Harbour. * [[Caraquet]]: Derived from the Mi'kmaq language, meaning "junction (or meeting) of two rivers".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ach/lr/ks/plc/nb-eng.asp |title=Government of Canada, Indian and Northern Affairs Canada – New Brunswick |accessdate=19 April 2009 |publisher=AINC-INAC.gc.ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613192102/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ach/lr/ks/plc/nb-eng.asp |archivedate=13 June 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cqsb.qc.ca/svs/434/fnplace.htm|title=Central Quebec School Board – Places & Origin of Names|accessdate=19 April 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025063252/http://www.cqsb.qc.ca/svs/434/fnplace.htm|archivedate=25 October 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[Escuminac, New Brunswick|Escuminac]] * [[Kennebecasis River]] *[[Kouchibouguac National Park]] (and [[Kouchibouguac River|River]]): ''Kouchibouguac'' means "river of the long tides" in [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]]. * [[Lake Magaguadavic|Magaguadavic Lake]], a Mi'kmaq word meaning "lake of eels". * [[Mactaquac, New Brunswick|Mactaquac]], a Maliseet word meaning "big branch". * [[Manawagonish Island]] * [[Meductic]] : derived from the Maliseet word "Medoctic", meaning "the end". * [[Meduxnekeag]] * [[Miramichi (disambiguation)|Miramichi]] : the name, which may be the oldest recorded name of aboriginal origin in Canada, may come from the [[Innu-aimun|Montagnais]] word for "country of the [[Mi'kmaq people|Micmac]]." * [[Nackawic]], which gets its name from the Maliseet word meaning "straight" or "not in the direction it seems to be", alluding to the illusion created at the intersection of the Nackawic Stream and the Saint John River. * [[Nashwaak River]] : a corruption of the [[Maliseet]] word for slow current. * [[Nashwaaksis]] * [[Nauwigewauk]] :probably means babbling brook * [[Oromocto]] : possibly from the [[Maliseet]] word welamooktook which means "good river" * [[Penniac, New Brunswick|Penniac]], meaning "fork in the river". * [[Penobsquis, New Brunswick|Penobsquis]] * [[Petitcodiac, New Brunswick|Petitcodiac]] – term is derived from a [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] word meaning "bends like a bow" (contradicts the popular belief that the name derived from the French term "petit coude", meaning "little elbow")[http://www.servinghistory.com/topics/Petitcodiac_River::sub::Etymology] * [[Pokiok]] * [[Quispamsis]] – translated from the Maliseet language and means, "little lake in the woods" (i.e., [[Ritchie Lake]]) * [[Shiketehauk River]] * [[Temisquata Lake]] * [[Washademoak Lake]] * [[Woolastook]] : Maliseet word meaning 'good and bountiful river'
===Newfoundland and Labrador=== *[[Aguathuna]]: possibly derives from the [[Beothuk language|Beothuk]] ''aguathoonet'' or ''aquathoont'', "grindstone", imposed perhaps in the mistaken belief that it meant "white rock" for the limestone abundant in the area [https://web.archive.org/web/20020725221405/http://home.cogeco.ca/~nfldroots/seart.htm] *[[Kaipokok Bay]]: from [[Inuktitut]], meaning "frothy water"[https://web.archive.org/web/20051103180226/http://www.nunatsiavut.com/en/makkovik.php] *[[Ktaqmkuk]]: Land over the water from [[Mi'kmaq language]] "Newfoundland" <ref>http://www.heritage.nf.ca/articles/aboriginal/mikmaq-land-claims.php</ref> *[[Makkovik]]: ''Vik'' is the [[Inuktitut]] word for "place". ''Makko-'' may have one of the following origins: # it may be a corruption of the name ''Maarcoux'', after [[Pierre Marcoux]], a French trader in [[Labrador]] in the late 18th century [https://www.mun.ca/educ/native_northern/makkovik.html]; or # from the [[Inuktitut]] ''maggok'', "two"; thus ''Makkovik'' would mean "two places". Around Makkovik are two inlets, Makkovik Bay and Makkovik harbour, and two main brooks floating into the two inlets. "Two Buchten Machovik", meaning "two bays Makkovik", is mentioned in a 1775 writing by the German [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] [[missionary]] [[Johann Ludwig Beck]].[http://www.labradorvirtualmuseum.ca/wem/CommunityProfile.html] *[[Natuashish]]: from [[Innu-aimun]], meaning "a small lake". [http://www.innuplaces.ca/fiche.php?id=221&lang=en] *[[Nunatsiavut]]: from [[Inuktitut]], meaning "our beautiful land"[https://web.archive.org/web/20100211182545/http://www.nunatsiavut.com/en/nunatsiavutgov.php] *[[Shannoc Brook]]: [[Joseph Beete Jukes]], the [[Geological Survey]]or of Newfoundland in 1839–1840, believed that Shannoc Brook, a tributary of the [[Exploits River]], was given the [[Beothuk language|Beothuk]] name for the [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]][https://web.archive.org/web/20020725221405/http://home.cogeco.ca/~nfldroots/seart.htm]. *[[Sheshatshiu, Newfoundland and Labrador|Sheshatshiu]]: from [[Innu-aimun]], meaning "a narrow place in the river".[https://web.archive.org/web/20060420040639/http://collections.ic.gc.ca/Labrador/sheshatshit2.html] *[[Torngat Mountains]]: from the [[Inuktitut]] name for the region, ''turngait'', meaning "spirits"; Inuit legends hold that here the spirit and physical worlds overlap.[https://web.archive.org/web/20051211072724/http://www.nunavik-tourism.com/adventuretorgnat.html] *[[Wabana, Newfoundland and Labrador|Wabana]] – from the [[Abenaki language|Abenaki]] ''wabunaki'', "east land" from ''wabun'' "dawn"; so named in 1895 by Colonel [[Thomas Cantley]], president of the [[Nova Scotia Steel Company]][http://bellisland.net/council/town_history.htm] *[[Wabush, Newfoundland and Labrador|Wabush]] – from [[Innu-aimun]] ''uapush'', "Arctic hare"[https://web.archive.org/web/20051025054039/http://www.labradorwest.com/wabush_crest.htm]
===Nova Scotia=== *[[Antigonish, Nova Scotia|Antigonish]]: Derived from the [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] word ''nalegitkoonechk'', meaning "where branches are torn off". *[[Baddeck, Nova Scotia|Baddeck]] *[[Chebucto Peninsula|Chebucto]] (the original name of [[City of Halifax|Halifax]] and the [[Halifax Harbour]]): Derived from the Mi'kmaq word "Jipugtug", meaning "the biggest harbour".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/comment/columnists/article/106631|title=The Toronto Star – Harbouring a host of delights|accessdate=19 April 2009|work=Toronto Star | first=Cleo | last=Paskal | date=10 June 2006}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mikmaqonline.org/servlet/words/Jipugtug.html|title=Mi'kmaq Online.org – Words, Pronunciation – Jipugtug (with audio clips)|accessdate=20 April 2009|publisher=MikmaqOnline.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.maplesquare.com/halifax/history.html |title=MapleSquare.com – Halifax's History – Jipugtug (or Chebucto) |accessdate=20 April 2009 |publisher=MapleSquare.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204115634/http://www.maplesquare.com/halifax/history.html |archivedate=4 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> *[[Cobequid Bay|Cobequid]]: Derived from the Mi'kmaq word "Wakobetgitk", meaning "end of the rushing or flowing water".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.ns.ca/cmns/msrv/nr-1997/nr97-06/97061002.htm|title=Gov.ns.ca – Transportation – Public Works – New highway named Cobequid Pass|accessdate=19 April 2009|publisher=Government of Nova Scotia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.acadian-cajun.com/cobequd.htm|title=Acadian-Cajun, Genealogy & History – Exile Destination – Cobequid|accessdate=19 April 2009|publisher=Acadian-Cajun.com}}</ref> *[[Ecum Secum, Nova Scotia|Ecum Secum]]: Derived from the Mi'kmaq language, meaning "a red house". *[[Eskasoni, Nova Scotia|Eskasoni]]: Derived from the [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] word ''We'kwistoqnik'', meaning "Where the fir trees are plentiful". *[[Kejimkujik National Park]]: "Kejimkujik" has been translated as meaning "attempting to escape" or "swollen waters", but the park's official translation means "tired muscles". *[[Malagash, Nova Scotia|Malagash]] *[[Merigomish, Nova Scotia|Merigomish]] *[[Mushaboom, Nova Scotia|Mushaboom]] *[[Musquodoboit Harbour]]: ''foaming to the sea''. The name is an anglicized version of the Mi’kmaq word ''Moosekudoboogwek''. *[[Nictaux, Nova Scotia]], meaning unknown *[[Pictou, Nova Scotia|Pictou]]: Derived from the Mi'kmaq word "Piktook", meaning "an explosion of gas".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.townofpictou.ca/pictou_history.html |title=TownOfPictou.ca – History of Pictou – By historian Ron Wallis |accessdate=19 April 2009 |publisher=TownOfPictou.ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319015217/http://www.townofpictou.ca/pictou_history.html |archivedate=19 March 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parl.ns.ca/placenames/pictoup.html#Pictou|title=Pictou-Antigonish Regional Library, County place names|accessdate=19 April 2009|publisher=PARL.ns.ca}}</ref> *[[Pugwash, Nova Scotia|Pugwash]]: Derived from the [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] word "pagwe’ak", meaning "deep water".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tatamagouche.com/history/ |title=Tatamagouche.com – Local Histories – Pugwash |accessdate=19 April 2009 |publisher=Tatamagouche.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225192719/http://tatamagouche.com/history/ |archivedate=25 February 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://travel.sympatico.msn.ca/DestinationGuides/Narrative.htm?destid=2969&recordid=2969010029 |title=Sympatico, MSN Travel – Nova Scotia's Northern Shore, Pugwash |accessdate=19 April 2009 |publisher=Sympatico.MSN.ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418025704/http://travel.sympatico.msn.ca/DestinationGuides/Narrative.htm?destid=2969&recordid=2969010029 |archivedate=18 April 2009 }}</ref> *[[Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia|Shubenacadie]]:Derived from the Mi'kmaq word Shubenacadie (or Segubunakade) means "abounding in ground nuts" or "place where the red potato grows. *[[Stewiacke, Nova Scotia|Stewiacke]]: Derived from the Mi'kmaq language, meaning "flowing out in small streams" and "whimpering or whining as it goes".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://museum.gov.ns.ca/mnh/nature/nhns2/500/511.htm|title=Museum, Government of Nova Scotia – 511 Windsor Lowlands|accessdate=19 April 2009|publisher=Museum.gov.ns.ca|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522030444/http://museum.gov.ns.ca/mnh/nature/nhns2/500/511.htm|archivedate=22 May 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *[[Tatamagouche, Nova Scotia|Tatamagouche]]: Derived from the [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] word ''takumegooch'', meaning "meeting of the waters". *[[Tracadie, Nova Scotia|Tracadie]] *[[Wagmatcook, Nova Scotia|Wagmatcook]] *[[Whycocomagh, Nova Scotia|Whycocomagh]]:Derived from a Mi'kmaq word which means "Head of the Waters".
===Northwest Territories=== {{Main|List of communities in the Northwest Territories}} *[[Aulavik National Park]], ''Aulavik'' means "place where people travel" in [[Inuvialuktun]] *[[Naats'ihch'oh National Park Reserve]], ''Naats'ihch'oh'' means "stands like a porcupine" in the [[Dene Suline language]] *[[Nahanni National Park Reserve]] and [[South Nahanni River]], from ''[[Nahani]]'' meaning "People over there far away" in the [[Dene]] language *[[Pingo National Landmark]], from ''[[Pingo]]'' an Inuvialuktun word for "small hill" *[[Slave River]], thought to come from the [[Athabaskan languages|Athabaskan]] ''Deh Gah Got'ine'', the name for the [[Slavey people|Slavey]] group of the Dene [[First Nations]] *[[Thaydene Nene National Park]], ''Thaydene Nene'' meaning "land of our ancestors" in the Dene language *[[Tuktut Nogait National Park]], ''Tuktut Nurrait'' means "young caribous" in Inuvialuktun
===Nunavut=== *[[Auyuittuq National Park]] – Auyuittuq means "the land that never melts". *[[Iqaluit]]: "many fish" in [[Inuktitut]]. *[[Pangnirtung]] is derived from ''Pangniqtuuq'': "the place of many bull caribou" *[[Quttinirpaaq National Park]] – ''Qutsiniqpaaq/Quttiniqpaaq'' means "top of the world" in [[Inuktitut]] and ''Quttiniqpaaq'' in [[Inuinnaqtun]]. *[[Sirmilik National Park]] – ''Sirmilik'' means "the place of glaciers" in [[Inuktitut]] and ''Hirmilik'' in [[Inuinnaqtun]]. *[[Ukkusiksalik National Park]] – ''Ukkusiksalik'' means "place of have cooking pots" in [[Inuktitut]] and ''Utkuhikhalik'' in [[Inuinnaqtun/Natsilik/Kivalliq]].
===Ontario===
*[[Adjala–Tosorontio|Adjala-Tosorontio]]:''Tosorontio'' is derived from the [[Wyandot language|Huron (Wyandot)]] word meaning "beautiful mountain", and ''Adjala'' was the name of the wife of Chief [[Tecumseh]]. *[[Algonquin Provincial Park]]: Named after the [[Algonquin people|Algonquin]] ([[Anishinaabe]]g) people of Ontario. *[[Almaguin Highlands]]: Derived from the words ''Algonquin'' and ''Magnetawan''. *[[Assiginack]] *[[Algoma District]] *[[Atikokan]]: [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] for "caribou bones." *[[Attawapiskat, Ontario|Attawapiskat]]: "People of the parting of the rocks" from the [[Swampy Cree language|Swampy Cree (Omushkegowuk)]] ''chat-a-wa-pis-shkag''.<ref name=CanoeAtlas>{{cite book |last1= Berger|first1= Jonathan|last2= Terry|first2= Thomas|title= Canoe Atlas of the Little North|year= 2007|location= [[Erin, Ontario|Erin, Ont.]]|publisher= Boston Mills Press|pages= 109, 111, 115|isbn = 978-1-55046-496-2|oclc= 78038334}} Also {{OCLC|174417835}}</ref> *[[Brantford, Ontario|Brantford]]: Named after [[Joseph Brant]], a [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]] leader. *[[Cataraqui River]] *[[Cayuga, Ontario|Cayuga]]: Named for the [[Cayuga people]] of Ontario. *[[Chinguacousy Township, Ontario|Chinguacousy]] *[[Lake Couchiching|Couchiching]]: Derived from the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] ''gojijiing'', meaning "inlet." *[[Deseronto]]: Named for [[John Deseronto|Captain John Deseronto]], a native [[Mohawk people|Mohawk]] leader who was a captain in the British Military Forces during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. *[[Guelph/Eramosa|Eramosa]]: Thought to be derived from the word ''un-ne-mo-sah'' (possibly meaning "black dog", "dead dog", or simply "dog"). *[[Esquesing Township]]: [[Mississaugas|Mississauga]] [[Anishinaabe]] word ''ishkwessin'', meaning "that which lies at the end", which was the original name for [[Bronte Creek]]. *[[Etobicoke]]: "The place where the [[alder]]s grow" from the word ''wadoopikaang'' in the [[Ojibwe language]]. *[[Fort Erie, Ontario|Fort Erie]]: [[Iroquoian languages|Iroquoian]], ''erige'', meaning "cat". *[[Gananoque, Ontario|Gananoque]]: Origin unknown, thought to be derived from Native languages for "place of health" or "meeting place" or "water running over rocks." *[[East Garafraxa|Garafraxa]]: Possibly derived from the word for "panther country". *[[Iroquois Falls]]: Named for the [[Iroquois|Iroquois people]] of Ontario. *[[Kakabeka Falls]]: From the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word ''gakaabikaa'', "waterfall over a cliff". *[[Kaministiquia River]]: Derived from ''gaa-ministigweyaa'', an [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word meaning "(river) with islands". *[[Kanata, Ontario|Kanata]]: [[Mohawk language|Mohawk]] word meaning "village" or "settlement." *[[Kapuskasing]]: Of [[Cree language|Cree]] origin, possibly meaning "bend in river." *[[Kawartha Lakes]]: An Anglicization of the word ''ka-wa-tha'' (from ''ka-wa-tae-gum-maug'' or ''gaa-waategamaag''), a word coined in 1895 by Martha Whetung of the [[Curve Lake First Nation]], meaning "land of reflections" in the [[Anishinaabe]] language. The word was subsequently changed by tourism promoters to ''Kawartha'', with the meaning "bright waters and happy lands." *[[Kenora|Keewatin]]: [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] for "north wind." Derived from either ''kīwēhtin'' in [[Cree language|Cree]] or ''giiwedin'' in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. *[[Greater Madawaska, Ontario|Madawaska]]: Named after an [[Algonquin people|Algonquian]] band of the region known as ''Matouweskarini'', meaning "people of the shallows". *[[Magnetawan]]: Derived from the word for "swiftly flowing river." *[[Manitoulin Island]]: ''Manitoulin'' is the [[English language|English]] version, via [[French language|French]], of the Old [[Ottawa dialect|Odawa]] name ''Manidoowaaling'', which means "cave of the spirit". *[[Manitouwadge, Ontario|Manitouwadge]]: From ''manidoowaazh'' in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]], meaning "cave of the spirit." *[[Assiginack|Manitowaning]] *[[Manotick]]: Derived from [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] for "island." *[[Matachewan, Ontario|Matachewan]] *[[Matawatchan, Ontario|Matawatchan]] *[[Mattawa, Ontario|Mattawa]]: "Meeting of the waters" in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. *[[M'Chigeeng, Ontario|M'Chigeeng]] *[[Michipicoten, Ontario|Michipicoten]]: "Big bluffs" in [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]]. *[[Missinaibi River|Missinaibi Provincial Park]]: [[Cree language|Cree]] for "pictured waters," thought to refer to the pictographs found on rock faces along the river. *[[Mississauga]]: Named for the native tribe of the [[Mississaugas]] *[[Mississippi Mills, Ontario|Mississippi Mills]]: May originate from ''Mazinaa[bikinigan]-ziibi'', [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] for "[painted] image river", referring to the pictographs found on [[Mazinaw Lake]]. *[[Moosonee]]: Derived from the [[Cree language|Cree]] word ''moosoneek'', meaning "at the [[Moose River (Ontario)|Moose (River)]]". *[[District Municipality of Muskoka|Muskoka]]: Named for a First Nations chief of the 1850s, Chief Yellowhead or ''Mesqua Ukie''. *[[Greater Napanee|Napanee]] *[[Nassagaweya Township, Ontario|Nassagaweya]]: Derived from the [[Mississaugas|Mississauga]] word ''nazhesahgewayyong'', meaning "river with two outlets." *[[Neebing, Ontario|Neebing]] *[[Niagara, Toronto|Niagara]]: [[Iroquois]] in origin, meaning uncertain. *[[Nipigon, Ontario|Nipigon]]: May have originated from the [[Ojibwe language|Ojibwe]] word ''animbiigoong'', meaning "at continuous water" or "at waters that extend [over the horizon]." *[[Nipissing, Ontario|Nipissing]]: From the [[Anishinaabe language|Anishinaabe]] term ''nibiishing'', meaning "at (some) water".<ref name="free" /> *[[Nottawasaga River]]: Derived from the [[Algonquin language|Algonquin]] words for "Iroquois" and "river outlet". *[[Ohsweken, Ontario|Ohsweken]] *[[Oneida Nation of the Thames]] *[[Onondaga Township, Ontario|Onondaga]] *[[Ontario]] *[[Opasatika]], "river lined with poplars". *[[Oshawa]]: from the [[Anishinaabe language|Ojibwe]] term ''aazhaway'', meaning "crossing to the other side of a river or lake" or just "(a)cross".<ref name="free">[http://www.freelang.net/dictionary/ojibwe.html Freelang Ojibwe Dictionary]</ref><ref>Rayburn, Alan, ''Place Names of Ontario'', Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 1997, p. 258.</ref> *[[Otonabee–South Monaghan|Otonabee]]: From the Ojibwe term "Odoonabii-ziibi" (Tullibee River). Otonabee comes from the words ode which means "heart" and odemgat that comes from "boiling water". It translates into "the river that beats like a heart in reference to the bubbling and boiling water of the rapids along the river" *[[Ottawa]]: "To buy" from the word ''adaawe'' in the [[Anishinaabe language]]; adapted as the name of the [[Odawa people]]. *[[Penetanguishene]]: believed to come from either the Wyandot language or from the Abenaki language via the Ojibwa language, meaning "land of the white rolling sands". *[[Petawawa, Ontario|Petawawa]]: From Algonquin meaning "where one hears the noise of the water" *[[Powassan]]: From the word for "bend." *[[Pukaskwa National Park]] *[[Saugeen Shores|Saugeen]]: Ojibwa language, Zaagiing, meaning outlet *[[Shawanaga Township, Ontario|Shawanaga]] *[[Scugog]]: Derived from the Mississauga word sigaog, which means "waves leap over a canoe." *[[Shuniah, Ontario|Shuniah]]: named after the Ojibwa word "zhooniyaa" for "money" or "silver" *[[Sioux Narrows-Nestor Falls|Sioux Narrows]] *[[Sioux Lookout]] *[[Tecumseh, Ontario|Tecumseh]] *[[Tehkummah]] *[[Temagami, Ontario|Temagami]]: from the [[Anishinaabe language|Anishinaabe]] word ''dimiigami'', "deep water(s)".<ref name="free" /> *[[Timiskaming (disambiguation)|Timiskaming]]: from the Algonquin language ''Temikami'' or ''Temikaming'', meaning "deep waters". *[[Toronto]]: from an Iroquoian language, but of uncertain derivation.<ref>Bright (2004:508–9)</ref> Another story says it is derived from the Mohawk word "tkaronto" meaning "trees standing in the water". *[[Tuscarora Township, Ontario|Tuscarora]] *[[Tyendinaga]]: Derived from a variant spelling of Mohawk leader Joseph Brant's traditional Mohawk name, Thayendanegea. *[[Wahnapitae, Ontario|Wahnapitae]]: from the Anishinaabe ''waanabide'', "be shaped like a hollow tooth".<ref name="free" /> *[[Wasaga Beach]]: Derived from "Nottawasaga," as above. *[[Wawa, Ontario|Wawa]] *[[Ashfield–Colborne–Wawanosh|Wawanosh]] *[[Wikwemikong, Ontario|Wikwemikong]]: from the Anishinaabe ''wiikwemikong'', "Bay of Beavers" from Nishnaabe word "Amik" meaning beaver.<ref name="free" /> *[[Plympton–Wyoming|Wyoming]]: derived from the Munsee name xwé:wamənk, meaning "at the big river flat."
===Quebec=== *[[Abitibi Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Abitibi]] *[[Aguanish, Quebec|Aguanish]] *[[Ahuntsic, Quebec|Ahuntsic]] district of [[Montreal]] *[[Akpatok Island, Quebec|Akpatok Island]] ''Akpaqtuq'' means "come down or lowers itself" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Amqui]] *[[Arthabaska, Quebec|Arthabaska]] (and [[Arthabaska County, Quebec|County]]) *[[Réservoir Cabonga, Quebec|Réservoir Cabonga]] *[[Caniapiscau Reservoir|Réservoir Caniapiscau]], and ([[Caniapiscau River|River]], [[Caniapiscau|Hunting camp]], [[Caniapiscau Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Regional county municipality]]) *[[Causapscal, Quebec|Causapscal]] *[[Chibougamau]] or Chibouagmou: *[[Chicoutimi]]: "End of the deep water" in [[Innu-aimun|Montagnais]]. *[[Coaticook, Quebec|Coaticook]]: Derived from the [[Abenaki]] language, meaning "river near the pines". *[[Donnacona, Quebec|Donnacona]]: Named after Chief [[Donnacona]], 16th century [[St. Lawrence Iroquoians|Iroquoian]] Chief of [[Stadacona]]. *[[Lac-Etchemin, Quebec|Lac-Etchemin]] (and town) *[[Gaspé, Quebec|Gaspé]] (also [[Gaspé County, Quebec|County]], [[Gaspé Peninsula|Peninsula]], and [[Gaspé Cape, Quebec|Cape]]): "land's end" in [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]]. *[[Inukjuak, Quebec|Inukjuak]] ''Inugjuaq or Inujjuaq'' means "The Giant/Big Man" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Kahnawake, Quebec|Kahnawake]] *[[Kamouraska County, Quebec|Kamouraska County]]: Derived from the [[Abenaki]] language, meaning "birch bark here". *[[Kangiqsualujjuaq, Quebec|Kangiqsualujjuaq]] ''Kangiqsualujjuaq'' means "the very large bay" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Kanesatake, Quebec|Kanesatake]] *[[Kenogami Lake|Lac Kénogami]]: ''Kenogami'' means "long water" in [[Innu-aimun|Montagnais]]. *[[Koksoak River|Rivière Koksoak]] ''Quqsuaq'' means "Yellowish" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Kuujjuaq, Quebec|Kuujjuaq]] ''Kuujjuaq'' means "the great river" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Lac Manitou, Quebec|Lac Manitou]]: Derived from the [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] name ''[[Gitchi Manitou]]'', which in their culture describes their Creator (the Great Spirit). *[[Maniwaki, Quebec|Maniwaki]] *[[Maskinongé, Quebec|Maskinongé]] (and [[Maskinongé County, Quebec|County]]) *[[Matane]] *[[Matane County, Quebec|Matane County]] *[[Matapédia County, Quebec|Matapédia County]] *[[Réservoir and Rivière Matawin, Quebec|Réservoir and Rivière Matawin]] *[[Magog, Quebec|Magog]]: Derived from "Memphremagog", see Lake Memphremagog below. *[[Manicouagan River]]: "where there is bark" *[[Mascouche]] *[[Mégantic County, Quebec|Mégantic County]] (also Lake): [[Abenaki]] for "lake trout place". *[[Lake Memphremagog, Quebec|Lac Memphremagog]]: Meaning "beautiful waters" or "vast expanse of water" in [[Abenaki]]. *[[Missisquoi County, Quebec|Missisquoi County]]: ''Missisquoi'' is an [[Abenaki]] tribal name. *[[Nastapoka Islands, Quebec|Nastapoka Islands]] *[[Oka, Quebec|Oka]] *[[Pohenegamook, Quebec|Pohenegamook]] *[[Pontiac County, Quebec|Pontiac County]]: Name of the famous 18th-century Ottawa leader [[Pontiac (Ottawa leader)|Pontiac]]. *[[Quebec City]] (and [[Quebec County, Quebec|County]], and [[Quebec|Province]]): The "narrowing of the river" refers to the point where the [[St. Lawrence River]] passes Quebec City. *[[Rimouski]] (and [[Rimouski County, Quebec|County]]) *[[Saguenay, Quebec|Saguenay]] *[[Salluit, Quebec|Salluit]] ''Salluit'' means "the thin ones" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Sayabec, Quebec|Sayabec]] *[[Shawinigan, Quebec|Shawinigan]]: "Portage at the crest" in [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]]. *[[Squatec, Quebec|Squatec]] *[[Tadoussac, Quebec|Tadoussac]] *[[Temiscamingue County, Quebec|Temiscamingue County]] *[[Témiscouata County, Quebec|Témiscouata County]]: [[Abenaki]] for "bottomless" or "extremely deep all around". *[[Torngat Mountains, Quebec|Torngat Mountains]] ''Tuurngat'' means "Spirits or sometimes Evils" in [[Inuktitut]] *[[Yamachiche, Quebec|Yamachiche]] *[[Yamaska County, Quebec|Yamaska County]]
===Saskatchewan=== *[[Assiniboia]] *[[Kenosee lake]] *[[Kinistino]] *[[Nipawin]] *[[Piapot]] *[[Saskatoon]]: Derived from the [[Cree]] word ''misāskwatōmin'', meaning [[Saskatoon berry]] – a fruit native to the area. *[[Wakaw]] *[[Waskesiu]] *[[Wawota]]
===Yukon=== *[[Aishihik Lake]] and [[Aishihik River]]: meaning "tail hanging down" in [[Southern Tutchone]] *[[Alsek River]] *[[Dezadeash Lake]] *[[Ivvavik National Park]]: ''Ivavik'' means "birthplace" or "nursery" in [[Inuvialuktun]] *[[Klondike, Yukon|Klondike]] and [[Klondike River]]: Derived from the [[Hän language]] word for hammer stones used to fix salmon nets (''Tr'ondëk''). *[[Kluane Lake]] and [[Kluane National Park and Reserve]]: from ''Łù'àn'' meaning big fish in [[Southern Tutchone]] *[[Klukshu]] and [[Klukshu River]] *[[Kusawa Lake]] *[[Nisutlin River]] *[[Tagish Lake]] and [[Tagish, Yukon]]: from the name of the language and people ([[Tagish]] Kwan) *[[Takhini River]] *[[Tatshenshini River]] *[[Teslin Lake]], [[Teslin River]] and [[Teslin, Yukon]]: from the [[Tlingit people|Tlingit]] ''Deisleen'', long narrow water *[[Vuntut National Park]]
==See also== {{Portal|Aboriginal peoples in Canada}} {{Main|Index of Aboriginal Canadian-related articles}} * [[List of English words from indigenous languages of the Americas]] * [[List of placenames of indigenous origin in the Americas]] * [[List of place names in New England of aboriginal origin]] * [[List of Indian reserves in Canada]] * [[List of Indian reserves in Canada by population]] * [[List of First Nations governments]] * [[List of First Nations peoples]] * [[Classification of indigenous peoples of the Americas]] * [[List of Chinook Jargon placenames]]

''Native American Placenames of the United States''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081025063252/http://www.cqsb.qc.ca/svs/434/fnplace.htm Central Quebec School Board] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050210060047/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/pr/info/info106_e.html Indian and Northern Affairs Canada] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090207222912/http://geonames.nrcan.gc.ca/index_e.php Geographical Names of Canada]
